title: 115_hr4911
content: The Act titled "Joint Commission on Budget Process Reform Act of 2018" establishes a Joint Commission on Budget Process Reform. The Joint Commission on Budget Process Reform is established as an independent commission with duties including studying budget procedures, conducting public hearings, seeking recommendations for reform, drafting a bill to amend the Congressional Budget Act, and submitting a report to Congress. The Joint Commission on Budget Process Reform will submit a report to Congress containing recommendations for bill amendments and other relevant issues. The report will include findings on topics such as ensuring timely completion of the budget process, addressing mandatory spending levels, implementing long-term debt limits, increasing transparency, considering a balanced budget amendment, enforcing a binding congressional budget, and reauthorizing the Congressional Budget Office. The Joint Commission on Budget Process Reform will address reauthorizing the Congressional Budget Office, changing the fiscal year to align with the calendar year, considering term limits for Budget Committee members, and comparing annual vs. biennial budgeting efficiency. The commission will consist of 23 members including the chair and ranking member of the House Budget Committee. Members of the House of Representatives involved in budget-related committees include the chairs and ranking members of the Budget, Appropriations, and Ways and Means Committees. The appointment process for nominees to budget-related committees includes various members from the House of Representatives and Senate, as well as key government officials, to be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Joint Commission on Budget Process Reform appoints members for the duration of the commission, with vacancies filled in the same manner as original appointments. The commission elects a legislator as chair and appoints a Director of Staff who is paid at the rate of level IV of the Executive Schedule. Additional staff can be appointed with commission approval. The Director of Staff may appoint additional personnel and the head of federal departments can detail their personnel to assist the commission. The staff of the commission is limited to 15 persons, and the Director can hire necessary staff. The commission can also procure temporary services from experts and consultants at specified rates. The joint commission under the General Schedule will have its first meeting within 30 days of the Act's enactment. $800,000 is authorized for funding, and travel expenses will be covered for members and staff following Government travel rules. SEC. 3. CONGRESSIONAL CONSIDERATION OF REFORM PROPOSALS. The introduction of a single bill in both the Senate and House of Representatives is required on the first day when both Houses are in session following the submission of a report containing the recommended bill to Congress. Members of the House of Representatives designated by the Speaker and minority leader must introduce implementation bills, which will be referred to the appropriate committees for consideration. If a committee fails to report the bill within 15 days, they will be discharged from further consideration. Upon being reported or discharged from the committee, an implementation bill shall be placed on the appropriate calendar for floor consideration. Any Member of the respective House can move to proceed to the consideration of the bill, with all points of order waived. The motion is privileged and not debatable in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The implementation bill in the Senate and House of Representatives is not debatable, amendable, or subject to postponement. A motion to reconsider the vote is not allowed. If the motion to proceed is agreed to, the bill remains unfinished business. The bill cannot be amended, and debate is limited to 10 hours divided equally between supporters and opponents. The implementation bill in the Senate and House of Representatives is not debatable, amendable, or subject to postponement. A motion to reconsider the vote is not allowed. The vote on final passage of the implementation bill shall occur immediately following the conclusion of the debate. Appeals from the decisions of the Chair relating to the application of the rules are allowed. Decisions of the Chair on rules for implementation bills are made without debate. If one House receives an implementation bill from the other House, it is not referred to a committee. The receiving House follows its normal procedure for the bill. The rules for implementation bills are decided by the Chair without debate. If one House receives a bill from the other House, it is not sent to a committee and the receiving House follows its usual procedure for the bill. Congress enacts this section as part of the rules of each House, applicable only to the procedure for implementation bills, superseding other rules if inconsistent. Each House has the constitutional right to change its rules regarding procedures at any time. The rules for implementation bills are decided by the Chair without debate. Each House has the constitutional right to change its rules regarding procedures at any time. The procedure of that House can be changed at any time, in the same manner, and to the same extent as in the case of any other rule of that House. SEC. 4. TERMINATION AND DISPOSITION OF RECORDS. The joint commission shall terminate within 2 years of enactment or upon the bill being signed into law. Its records will become those of the Committees on the Budget of the House of Representatives and the Senate.
